O\u2019Brien v. O\u2019Brien, 48 Mass. A.raw_text: O’Brien v. O’Brien, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 479 (2000) (considerations for modification and best interests analysis).
O\u2019Brien v. O\u2019Brien, 48 Mass. A.proposition: Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court decisions establishing that custody modifications require a showing of a material change in circumstances and must be decided based on the child’s best interests:
O\u2019Brien v. O\u2019Brien, 48 Mass. A.case_name: Composto v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
O\u2019Brien v. O\u2019Brien, 48 Mass. A.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns negligence, jury instructions, and preservation of objections in a tort case involving the MBTA; it does not address custody, domestic relations, or standards for modifying custody orders. There is no discussion of ‘material change in circumstances’ or a ‘best interests of the child’ analysis. The citation is therefore inaccurate for the stated family-law proposition.
O\u2019Brien v. O\u2019Brien, 48 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: However, the fact that Fairview had been defaulted was not relevant to a determination of the MBTA’s liability. Here, the plaintiffs’ case was based on the theory that the MBTA was negligent in entrusting keys to the escalator to Fairview’s employee without proper instruction or supervision as to its use. The judge properly instructed the jury that the MBTA could not be held liable for the actions of a person who was not its employee but could be held liable if the jury determined that the MBTA was itself negligent…

Goldman v. Goldman, 402 Mass. 56 (1988).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns review of a Massachusetts Commissioner of Insurance decision regarding medical malpractice insurance rates and related statutory issues; it does not address family law, custody determinations, or parental fitness. There is no discussion of standards for custody modification, material change in circumstances, or best interests of the child. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition regarding custody modification requirements.
Goldman v. Goldman, 402 Mass. 56 (1988).relevant_excerpt: N/A – the opinion contains no discussion of child custody, parental fitness, or standards for modifying custody orders.

Murphy v. Murphy, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 411.raw_text: Murphy v. Murphy, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 411 (1996) (material change and child’s welfare).
Murphy v. Murphy, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 411.proposition: Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court decisions establishing that custody modifications require a showing of a material change in circumstances and must be decided based on the child’s best interests:
Murphy v. Murphy, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 411.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal drug-trafficking and search-and-seizure case; it does not concern family law, custody, or modification of custody orders. The court nowhere discusses standards for modifying child custody, material change in circumstances, or best interests of a child. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the claimed custody‑modification proposition and appears to be a miscitation or wrong case reference.
Murphy v. Murphy, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 411.relevant_excerpt: In summary: Following the stop of a car on the highway, the car was impounded, and inventory searches disclosed some 14.6 grams of cocaine in a jacket hung over the driver’s seat and a larger quantity in a suitcase in the trunk. The defendant, one of the passengers, was indicted for trafficking in the larger amount. ... We hold that the car was impounded lawfully. The Commonwealth established the constructive possession, but failed on the alternative joint venture theory.

Brown v. Brown, 404 Mass. 187 (1989) (cu.raw_text: Brown v. Brown, 404 Mass. 187 (1989) (custody and best interest factors).
Brown v. Brown, 404 Mass. 187 (1989) (cu.proposition: Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court decisions establishing that custody modifications require a showing of a material change in circumstances and must be decided based on the child’s best interests:
Brown v. Brown, 404 Mass. 187 (1989) (cu.support_reasoning: This decision is a paternity and child support case under G.L. c. 209C, focusing on preclusion, separation of powers, and jury trial rights. It does not concern custody, modification of custody orders, or articulate the standard that custody modifications require a material change in circumstances and a best-interests analysis. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the custody-modification proposition stated.
Brown v. Brown, 404 Mass. 187 (1989) (cu.relevant_excerpt:
We conclude that this action may properly be maintained on behalf of the minor plaintiff, but that it must be dismissed as to the department.

3. Because we conclude that the minor plaintiff may maintain this action, we reach the question whether the defendant may properly be denied a jury trial. The defendant argues that he is entitled to a jury trial even though G. L. c. 209C, § 12, provides otherwise (“[i]n actions under this chapter, the trial shall be by the court without a jury”).

Santos v. Santos, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 227.raw_text: Santos v. Santos, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 227 (1992) (parenting time modifications).
Santos v. Santos, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 227.proposition: Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court decisions establishing that custody modifications require a showing of a material change in circumstances and must be decided based on the child’s best interests:
Santos v. Santos, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 227.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns damages for breach of a commercial lease and the landlord’s duty to mitigate; it does not involve child custody or parenting time, nor any standard for modifying custody orders. There is no discussion of ‘material change in circumstances’ or ‘best interests of the child.’ The citation to this case for the stated custody‑modification proposition is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s holding or reasoning.
Santos v. Santos, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 227.relevant_excerpt: At common law there was no duty by a landlord to mitigate damages if a tenant vacated the leased premises. Fifty Assocs. v. Berger Dry Goods Co., 275 Mass. 509, 514 (1931). A lease, after all, was the grant of an estate in land, and the landlord owed the tenant only quiet enjoyment. The tenant was the owner of the leased premises for a term and if the tenant chose to abandon the premises, that was no concern of the landlord.

F.A. v. J.P., 77 Mass. M.P. v. L.P., 442 Mass. 123 (2004) (cons.raw_text: M.P. v. L.P., 442 Mass. 123 (2004) (consideration of parental stability and housing in custody decisions).
M.P. v. L.P., 442 Mass. 123 (2004) (cons.proposition: Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court decisions establishing that custody modifications require a showing of a material change in circumstances and must be decided based on the child’s best interests:

L.P., 442 Mass. 123 (2004), and it does not concern custody, parental stability, housing, or modification standards. M.P. v. L.P., 442 Mass. 123 (2004) (cons.relevant_excerpt: “We must decide whether an alternative education program located in Boston, ABCD University High School, can be a ‘secondary school’ within the meaning of G. L. c. 94C, § 32J, the school zone statute… We conclude that the Commonwealth is entitled to relief.”

Calvo v. Calvo, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (200.raw_text: Calvo v. Calvo, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2007) (factors considered when modifying custody/parenting time).
Calvo v. Calvo, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (200.proposition: Appeals Court and Supreme Judicial Court decisions establishing that custody modifications require a showing of a material change in circumstances and must be decided based on the child’s best interests:
Calvo v. Calvo, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (200.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Calvo v. Calvo and does not concern custody or parenting time at all; it is a criminal case about venue for statutory rape prosecutions and violations of an abuse prevention order. It therefore does not address, much less establish, the rule that custody modifications require a material change in circumstances and must be based on the child’s best interests. The citation is inaccurate for the stated proposition.
Calvo v. Calvo, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (200.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 265, § 24A, is a quintessential statutory enactment which reflects the legislative discretion recognized in Opinion of the Justices, supra, to provide wide latitude for certain sex-related crimes by setting venue in dual counties for criminal prosecutions, “consistent with the public interest and the interests of justice.” Cf. Commonwealth v. Libby, 358 Mass. 617, 620 n.2 (1971) (“With respect to the offences of kidnapping and rape, there is wide latitude in trying a defendant in either the county from which or the county to which the victim was taken,” citing G. L. c. 265, §§ 24A, 27).
